positive.review:
Playing since 2012 - its a fun little time waster and can get pretty competitive at later tiers

The game has had huge overhauls since launch, namely the gold rounds no longer costing actual gold, physics, graphical updates and more recently the introduction of wheeled vehicles, double barrelled tanks and now Tier XI

There is still some obvious pay2win in terms of rarer vehicles usually only exclusive to clan wars or the tedious campaign missions 

Its worth saying that this also isn't War Thunder, its an arcade free-to-play tank battle game - there isn't any simulation nor 'realism' at all.
WoT 2.0 - Get yourself a free Tier X tank and play until your premium runs out comrade.

Overall good game. Total playtime 2000h+, just recently migrated from win to linux and it's easier to play through steam (proton) than wine and the wargaming client.

++Tank RPG, if you like historical/theoretical tanks you'll love this game.
++Mods
+Gameplay
+New content comes regularly
+Well maintained

-Matchmaking is sometimes total bs
-Hidden elo system (XVM mod fixes this but it should not need 3rd party mod to see)
-Monetization (everything is overpriced, but a small plus for "not being pay2win")
-Crappy UI in garage. Hardest of all games to find things.

I have uninstalled many times and reinstalled as many times.
Best enjoyed in few month periods to avoid boredom.
not as realistic or has as many vehichles as warthunder but i feel that both games are very different and both are good

I have spent way too much time playing the smaller version of this game and could not wait to try this. The graphics and gameplay are as fun as they look in-store, and having hundreds of tanks to chose from is really nice as there is always something new to get (although there is no way you could ever master 1/8 of them). The maps are really nice (mainly because of their size, slamming people with an E100 from 2 miles away is something Blitz can't offer). However the game  definitely has it's problems. Pay to win is very real, the surplus of bots are annoying, nerfing/buffing almost all historical vehicles makes them unreconizable (e.g. the Tiger has the King Tiger's gun) and grinding takes forever. I realize that complaining about having to work a game to have fun in it is kind of dumb, as someone who has put one thousand hours into the lite version of this taking 100 hours to get a tier X is really stupid. I can also see why giving out free Tier Xs is annoying, but getting the E100, E75, King Tiger and more for free was really nice (note that I have played this line for 500 hours in blitz so hopefully I know what I am doing in X matches lol) but people who don't know how to scope yet with Xs are very annoying. Someone also mentioned how bad the UI is and they are very right. I still have no idea how to do 7/10s of the things in the garage. So yeah, overall, probably 7/10, if you want to put the time and effort into this you need to actually have fun.

I'm playing since 2012, so add few thousand hours to my play time. Overall it's a good game. Despite its many flaws and questionable/controversial (greed) decisions made by the developers, I keep playing and I'm having fun.
It's a complex game which makes it hard for new players and after 15 years of this game's lifetime senior players will have many advantages. But on the other hand right now it's the easiest to get started and the most new player friendly this game has ever been.
Free to play aspect is to be taken with a grain of salt as playing on higher tiers will bankrupt you sooner or later without premium account, but there are many ways to get many days for free, mainly through Twitch.
Also it's very well optimized, so it runs on a toaster without issues. It also runs fine on Linux with Proton.

World of Tanks is a frustrating but fun Game, more frustrating for new Player because even with the Tutorial it takes a lot of Time to understand how to play properly.

It is obviously a Pay to Progress Game, (and since certain Tanks are locked behind Gold or Bundles a bit P2W) but with lots of Grinding (and mental Health) you can still do good Progress.

Big Thing i like is that the Developer still show Love to their Game by adding new Stuff like Tanks, Maps, machanics and even adjusting current mechanics to make them better, more balanced and easier to understand.

While it has some Positive Things it still has Flaws like the Matchmaking, it is very annoying to play with and against Tanks that are 2 Tiers over you because these Tanks are obviously way stronger than yours.
Another thing is the Progress, for someone that has a fulltime job, a family, real life hobbys or other games Grinding for better Tanks after reaching a certain Point takes a lot and i mean a lot of Time.

So do i want to keep playing that Game:                             YES
Do i want to Cry because of my own stupidity:                    YES
Do i want to rage on my stupid Teammates:                       YES
Do i recommend this Game so others feel the same Pain: YES
Great game, even with the tier XI what's in development. Makes it intresting to play more

My favorite tank game.

1K+ hours, 30K battles — but that doesn't really matter in this game. Hours and battles played aren't metrics we use to determine skill. We use WN8 and win rate. So, as a 2600 WN8, 57% WR player, I have some pro tips for total newbies.

1. Money spending: You don't need a premium account or premium tanks. At lower tiers (1–6), they're not necessary.
2. Don't rush to higher tiers (7–11): You'll get destroyed if you do. That's fine — I enjoy my 5K+ damage games, thanks.
3. Starting tank lines: You open the game for the first time — so many tanks to grind! Which line to start? USSR — go 
    for the IS-7 or Obj. 430U line. It's your best bet as a beginner. If you have a competent friend to teach and play with, 
    pick whatever line you like.
4. What you need to succeed:
   1. Study maps and positioning — learn key spawn points, flanks, and sniping spots for each map.
   2. Learn vision and concealment mechanics, including view range and bush effectiveness.
   3. Study penetration, shell types, and armor angling — these determine whether your shots deal damage.
   4. Develop situational awareness: Constantly check the minimap for enemy movements and team positioning.
5. That's a lot to take in, and you're probably too lazy to study — like most of us. Your best bet is to observe Unicum 
    players (top 1%) to understand decision-making, timing, and map control.
6. Streamers/YouTubers worth checking out: QuickyBaby, Skill4ltu, Dakillzor, Kajzoo, Iyouxin — but above them all, 
    Chems, my Black-Asian mom YouTuber. Go subscribe to him — he's very entertaining.
If you have any questions, leave a comment.

Poetic Review: "A tank consists of millions of parts. The most important one is you."
The synergy between sapiens and the machines forged from an altered, refined nature has always defined the arc of human conflict. In the long chronology of warfare, no clash mirrored this fusion more than Kursk. World of Tanks and World of Tanks Blitz extend this legacy into a digital arena, an endless Kursk, where the boundary between human and machine is tested again and again. Tech trees expand, armor lines evolve, and engines grow louder, yet one element remains unchanged: the trace of the self, the imprint of character, the role of the tool shaped by human intention.

Formal Review: World of Tanks is a deliberate tactical vehicle shooter that rewards map knowledge, positioning discipline, teamplay harmony, and long-term battlefield awareness. With its extensive lineup of nations, tech trees, and vehicle classes (each offering distinct armor profiles, gun characteristics, and battlefield roles), the game delivers deep strategic variety, making every match genuinely unique. While balance patches, matchmaking, monetization practices, and RNG-dependent engagements can be frustrating at times, the core loop of observing, aiming, positioning, angling, spotting, and timing remains consistently engaging. Rotating events and alternative modes provide welcome diversity beyond standard random battles. Wargaming can be generous at times and overly profit-driven at others, but for players who enjoy calculated maneuvers, thoughtful engagements, coordinated teamplay, and drawn-out yet decisive firefights, World of Tanks stands as one of the strongest tactical-action strategy games in the genre.

Well I figured I would nominate WoT for the steam awards, and give it a review. I have been playing off and on since closed beta, and much has changed over the years. 

The recent version 2.0 update and the gifts they gave were quite nice, it really got me back into the game a bit more. Another big change which happened a bit before that, was being allowed to finally play with an existing WoT account on steam. WoT had been on steam for some time, but only recently could we finally link our old accounts. There are several reasons to play WoT on steam, in my experience. Perhaps the biggest for me is that the steam platform seems a lot faster to download and update games than the WG center, especially for those of us with fast computers and fast internet (gigabit fiber). This is probably thanks partly to the fast steam download servers, but even patching after the download is also faster, so steam must just be more efficient in that regard. 

The game isn't perfect, whether on steam or WG center, my main complaints are balance in some battles, and with the match maker overall, and powercreep/changing meta, particularly related to balance of light tanks/spotters. Also the grind can be tedious. And of course buying premium tanks is bad for your wallet. 

Overall though, I do like the game, and I think it is good that it has received continued support after all these years, particularly in terms of easy integration with steam.

Now don't get me wrong, you will spend the upper tiers being bombarded by people with too much time and money invested in the game but in the lower tiers, you can have the fun. If you want to be free to play, stay under tier 7, if you are willing to spend money on the fancy ammo and all the upgrades, tiers 7 & above can be a blast. If you don't though, be prepared for a slog with the odd fun game to keep you hooked in a 15 year old game that somehow will still want £70+ for a single tank everyone will know the exact spot to shoot to remove you from the game 0.3 second after you get into a skirmish regardless as to how small that spot seems to you.

I first played World of Tanks more than ten years ago. Most of my complaints about the game back then are still true to this day - unlocking stuff can feel very grindy, the learning curve is tremendous, and the community is full of literal raging children and drunks who make muting team chat a wise choice.

And yet, with the 2.0 update, and tons of free stuff thrown my way for having an old account, I can't help but find myself wanting to play every single day. 

While tank-based combat in games like Battlefield can feel pretty one-dimensional, WoT's physics based damage modeling makes good aim secondary to good decision-making and map and tank knowledge and awareness. Some elements of the game, such as having a fully-upgraded, crewed, and supplied tank, can be rapidly accelerated by spending real $$$ on the game, and do make playing the game significantly more enjoyable. So less pay-to-win and more pay-to-have-fun than others in the F2P space.

Don't get too hung up on the silliness of the TI-III tanks and their go-kart experience, the game definitely gets more fun the higher you go on the tech tree, for better or worse. Finally, this is a game for relatively patient people - if you blindly rush into combat every game, you'll be literally bankrupted and forced to spend money to keep playing like a goon.

negative.review:
Veteran since 2015, took a break and came back 3yrs later. Some people say its P2W but I don't see it. It's more like gambling. A lot of times it will feel rigged as many have pointed out. Matches often times end in the first 3 minutes, giving you no chance other than being a punching xp bag. To keep it short here is my list of issues with the game. 

1. Spot mechanics
2. RNG
3. MM
4. tank balance 
5. Gold spammers 
6. Map layout
7. Arty

Those will be your biggest enemies. I could go into detail on each one but that will some time, plus there are other reviews pointing out at those issues. So, no I don't recommend this game. If you are new you will have to grind a lot, learn the tanks roles which often times it won't really matter and be in a world of pain. Just recently WG is giving a free tier X line as a tease. If you are a veteran coming back after a long absent you know what to expect because nothing has change really.

Bro this game is a certified war crime against fun. I’ve seen crack addicts with better life decisions than the clowns defending this garbage. “Free to play” my hairy asshole—unless you swipe the credit card harder than a porn star on OnlyFans you’re just free XP piñata for gold-spamming premium tryhards.
Matchmaker is drunk, blindfolded, and actively hates you. It sniffs your tank, goes “lol this guy breathes oxygen,” and instantly drops you into a city map with your open-top paper TD or a fucking prokhorovka when you’re rocking a slow-ass heavy with 2000 HP and a wet noodle gun. Zero fucking warning, zero map vote, zero brain cells in the code.
Loadouts? Cute. Consumables? LMAO pay up or eat shit, comrade. Half the team is bots or window-lickers who think holding W and left-click is peak strategy. Chat’s deader than my will to live after a few games, no VoIP, so good luck coordinating with 14 random mouth-breathers who play like they’re allergic to winning.
Platoons max at 3 so you need a premade duo just to not bleed IQ points every match, meanwhile the enemy has three unicum sweat-lords focus-firing your sorry ass the second you peek because the matchmaker saw you had a 51% winrate and decided “nah, fuck this guy in particular.”
I’ve had more fun shoving pineapples up my ass than grinding this rigged casino of depression. Devs, either fix your dogshit game or just delete it and save the ozone layer from all the rage-heated PCs. I’m out. Peace. ✌️

New players might as well stay away. The skill gap is too large and the game creators still REFUSE to impose a soft skill based match maker. They still think balancing tank types is key. They ruined the majority of the maps turning them into one trick pony maps. Maps used to cater to a wide variety of tanks. Select brawler and press 2 (Premium ammo).  Spam and hope the RNG allows you to win. RNG is on everything. It's a big reason a lot of players quit. They refuse to reduce the RNG from 25%. This means if you have a shell that has 100MM of penetration, and you aim it for a weak spot.... But the weak spot is 80MM of armor... You could low roll the penetration and still bounce your shot (Another reason most people spam premium ammunition). I don't mind the RNG on damage. Penetration should be penetration or at least the % reduced. As well for people who take the time to aim in. Should be no reason for a fully aimed shot that fills the reticle to drop out.

[h2]Perfect game - for unemployed people only[/h2]

Okay this game could be actually decent fun but there is a fundamental flaw in the game design. 

This game is solely focussed on the "whales" of online-gaming so the playerbase is always dying and diminishing itself. The free to play gameplay is basically non-existent but even with a lot of money you won't get very far quickly because they don't even sell the good tanks most of the time. 

There is a very large number of tanks in this game and a very small number of tanks that will not result in you dying immediately. But most of the good tanks are not only locked behind a paywall - you also need to put in 12 hours of gameplay with no sleep everyday to make some meaningful progress. 

Onslaught is one of the most abysmal game modes in the history of gaming because you will only get rewarded once you hit at least silver rank - which is an "average rank"in onslaught but it's not for average players because only the very best players of standard mode even bother playing it anymore. So basically you are up against people with no life playing this game for ten thousands of hours and if you can't achieve one of the best performances among them well ... bad for you ...you don't just earn slightly less rewards you basically get nothing. 

If you think of playing this game for maybe 3 hours a day and can spent 20$ a month on it - go somewhere else. In order to have fun in World of Tanks you need about 10+ hours a day and also spent 100$ of your hard earned social welfare benefits every month.

It's kinda fun, but they think of everything they possibly can to suck money from you. Think of every scummy microtransaction tactic and put it into a game.

I'm thinking of blocking WoT clip channels on youtube just so they can stop psyoping me into reinstalling the game.

Wargaming 'World of Tank' is one of the most beautiful graphical interface game however, that is where the praise ends. The game and mechanics can be frustrating, along with the game progress to build powerful, versatile tanks. The maps loop regularly, and it's about 8-9 that rotate mostly by switching you to the opposite side of the map.
Another point is by playing with random people, to complete the battlement requirements in the queue you're placed with people whom have developed skills as well those whom don't give a f*** about winning and just go on their own leaving you vulnerable. Highly any teamwork in a team based game. 
I DO NOT recommend this game to anyone. Please refrain from downloading or spending much time in it.

One-trick pony. Nothing new or interesting every year, gets boring after Tier 9. Events never seem to add anything interesting, always reusing same single map. Feels like League of Legends with 90% less features. The only worthwhile event I'd find is the battle royale "Steel Hunt" event. Otherwise, unbalanced, classic freemium business model. 

Same type of nonsensical RNG-dependant combat with the same type of tanks being released every year. Sit behind rock, expose turret with 0.5pixel wide weakspot with autobounce angles, shoot at other tanks sitting behind rock, exposing turret with 0.5pixel wide weakspot. Shoot at each other until out of ammo or one side decides to push into death.

I'd play the WoT Classic event, if it were more common. Old game used to feel like something, now it's just worth no time. They add something, but honestly add nothing.

Not to mention the ridiculous gambling support they add to a PEGI-12 game, backed by lame excuses, lead by the lamest community department leader eekeeboo.

A great concept of a multiplayer tank game, however most matches are characterized by frustration due to a number of issues.   Maps are not well balanced for vehicle type, so for any given map you usually find yourself functionally relegated to a small zone or else heavily handicapped.  If you are someone who values an historical experience you will find higher tier matches populated by hypothetical tanks with powerful mechanics (e.g. double barrels, gatling guns, fast autoloaders) that make you feel outmatched.  Lastly, players can pay money to purchase tanks and equipment that confer a significant advantage. 

The lower tier matches (III - VI or so) do have vehicles and an experience that feels more equitable and historical so it can be fun, although map imbalance is a persistent issue.  Also, you can team up with friends and play together which increases the enjoyment in any given match.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I am a veteran player of nearly 10 years, so I think I know a thing or two about the game. Here's my take on the game:

PRO

- Graphics: The game looks great, running on a custom-designed graphics engine which has surprisingly moderate system requirements
- There are many different tanks to research
- WoT features lots of community events; there's something new almost every week
- Games can be entered quickly, and servers are generally quite stable

CON

- Strong pay-to-win aspects. Some examples: new premium tanks are mostly stronger than researchable tech tree tanks (used to be different btw), playing high tier matches is hardly an option unless you invest money, premium ammunition and other consumables that provide a distinct advantage cost a lot of credits (which again are difficult to afford without paying real money) ... etc.

- Premium tanks are very expensive, with a single tank often costing 30 Euros and more (To be fair, it is not really necessary to buy too many, though)

- The WoT community is probably among the most toxic among all online games - certainly the worst I know, by a mile. So toxic, in fact, that there is a series of YouTube videos dedicated to demonstrate just how destructive players sometimes are

- Poor map designs: Many maps are one-sided (i.e. favour spawn points), offer little variation or are really too small for the capabilities of the tank tiers that can play on them. Note that this is not true for all of them, of course; some are really great, but notably the more recent ones are mostly really poor

- Extremely poor game balancing: This is the easily worst aspect of the game, and it comes in many shapes. Some examples:

* Although there are exceptions in every tech tree, it is an open secret that certain nations are quite consistently better than others in the game. Not that Wargaming would ever admit that, of course.
* Wargaming has a policy of rewarding the strongest players with the strongest tanks, so in high tier matches inexperienced players are put at an extra disadvantage
* Some tank classes are extremely difficult to counter (artilleries, wheeled tanks with an absurd auto-aim while moving).
* Due to the nature of matchmaking you will frequently find yourself in matches where you can do next to nothing
* The disparities in strength between tanks of the same Tier are often hair-raising. On Tier VIII, for example, a handful of tanks (mostly premium, of course) are so utterly dominant that the rest might as well not be in the game.

and and and ...

All in all, I would not recommend WoT to any new players anymore. It really isn't a particularly good game now; Wargaming have made too many poor design decisions over the past few years - the introduction of the stupefyingly idiotic wheeled tanks was just one example among many. It is true that it still has no equal in its niche, so if somebody wants to play a fast-paced tank shooter, it's probably this or nothing. However, those new players who are giving it a go should prepare for a game experience that is 10% fun and 90% frustration, and that frustration will way too often not be caused by their own inadequacy, but by poor game design.

TL,DR: Spare yourself the frustration, play something that is actually fun. It's not like there aren't plenty of great games out there.

New players will get clobbered in T3 with gold ammo from all directions. The spotting mechanic is completely unintuitive and the gap between trained crews and starters is still ridiculous, bordering on unplayable. Even 2.0 is not really worth the time. Take the gifts, play a couple games and uninstall.

World of Warships is the superior game in basically every aspect.

Veteran since 2015, took a break and came back 3yrs later. Some people say its P2W but I don't see it. It's more like gambling. A lot of times it will feel rigged as many have pointed out. Matches often times end in the first 3 minutes, giving you no chance other than being a punching xp bag. To keep it short here is my list of issues with the game. 

1. Spot mechanics
2. RNG
3. MM
4. tank balance 
5. Gold spammers 
6. Map layout
7. Arty

Those will be your biggest enemies. I could go into detail on each one but that will some time, plus there are other reviews pointing out at those issues. So, no I don't recommend this game. If you are new you will have to grind a lot, learn the tanks roles which often times it won't really matter and be in a world of pain. Just recently WG is giving a free tier X line as a tease. If you are a veteran coming back after a long absent you know what to expect because nothing has change really.
